[GRAMMAR]: "The dusky fellows must have been not a little delighted"
"But very soon the matter was fruited abroad"
"The king of Mitani was drawn up" (should be "The letters of the king of Mitani were drawn up")
"the terror of his name did not die with him, but for long did good service to his successors" (awkward phrasing)
"the first of whom, Amenophis II., seems moreover himself to had maintained"

[STRUCTURE]: The transition between the discovery of the tablets and the discussion of the Egyptian court is abrupt.
[LOGIC]: The connection between the scribes' use of Babylonian and the description of the Egyptian court is not clearly established.
[CLARITY]: The reference to "Pharaoh" and its absence in the Tell el Amarna documents is mentioned but not fully explained.
The meaning of "Manakhbiria" is not explained for the reader.
[TRANSITION]: The shift from the discussion of the tablets to the history of the Pharaohs is not smoothly connected.

[GRAMMAR]: "is roused to more aggressive measures by the resistance of the powerful priests of Amon in Thebes." (subject-verb agreement issue)
"The king alter his throne-name" (missing verb tense)
[SPELLING]: "Ai, called Haya in the Amarna letters, was probably a secretary of state, and was once sent as a special ambassador to Babylonia." (awkward phrasing)
[SYNTAX]: "The official world promptly broke with the old religion." (vague and awkward phrasing)
[LEXICON]: "The doctrine, as the new dogmas were called in inscriptions at Tell el Amarna, was regarded as so entirely a matter of home politics in Egypt..." (repetition and wordiness)

[LOGIC]: Sudden shift from the religious reform to the naming of officials and their roles without clear transition
The mention of foreign officials and their responses to the reform is abrupt and not well integrated into the main narrative
[STRUCTURE]: The text jumps between the religious context, political implications, and administrative details without clear organization
[CLARITY]: "The command to build the new city had not long been issued, and the place is still altogether unfinished." (confusing reference to past and present)
[TRANSITION]: Lack of clear transitions between the religious reform and the list of officials who adopted the new doctrine
